Darkness at the Window
Monster Rancher Metropolis: Library: Fan Fiction, Poetry, Birthday List, Links & Non-Fiction Archive: Poetry: Darkness at the Window
By TemateBaku on Saturday, August 7, 2004 - 02:03 pm:

The Ripper was fading,
into the night,
exhausted and weak,
after the flight.

A rustle was heard,
and with his last breath,
he set at a run,
to challenge his death.

Charging for freedom,
but slipping away,
darkness takes him,
and there he lay.

A laugh in the forest,
and the attacker moves on,
to the nearby ranch,
its best monster far gone.

A step on the porch,
and the breeder awakes,
seeing naught but a shadow,
sleep again he takes.

Through the window pane,
a shape can bee seen-
that of a wolf,
eyes darting and keen.

The attacker takes flight,
satisfied with the plunder,
the breeder's treasure is taken,
heard is the sound of thunder.

The assailant leaves a mark,
that of a bolt burnt in the ground,
then he leaves the ranch,
not again making a sound.

The breeder awakes,
finding his Ripper out cold,
he runs back to the ranch,
and the story is unfold.

He begins to remember,
and suddenly cries "No!",
the step on the porch,
and the darkness at the window.

By orangestar on Sunday, August 8, 2004 - 04:16 am:

Great poem!

By King Bunny on Sunday, August 8, 2004 - 01:09 pm:

Little off beat in some places and last line of 2nd to last stanza does sound that alright...

Otherwise great poem, would love to read more.

By Icelord13 on Sunday, August 8, 2004 - 06:55 pm:

Yeah, last line of 2nd stanza is improper grammar. It would be "unfolded" which wouldn't rhyme. How about, "and the story is told"?
